author: HCAndersen
text: THERE was once a darning-needle who thought herself so fine that she fancied she must be fit for embroidery.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Hold me tight," she would say to the fingers, when they took her up, "don't let me fall; if you do I shall never be found again, I am so very fine."

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is your opinion, is it?" said the fingers, as they seized her round the body.

author: HCAndersen
text: "See, I am coming with a train," said the darning-needle, drawing a long thread after her; but there was no knot in the thread.

author: HCAndersen
text: The fingers then placed the point of the needle against the cook's slipper.

author: HCAndersen
text: There was a crack in the upper leather, which had to be sewn together.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What coarse work!" said the darning-needle, "I shall never get through.

author: HCAndersen
text: I shall break!- I am breaking!" and sure enough she broke.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Did I not say so?" said the darning-needle, "I know I am too fine for such work as that."

author: HCAndersen
text: "This needle is quite useless for sewing now," said the fingers; but they still held it fast, and the cook dropped some sealing-wax on the needle, and fastened her handkerchief with it in front.

author: HCAndersen
text: "So now I am a breast-pin," said the darning-needle; "I knew very well I should come to honor some day: merit is sure to rise;" and she laughed, quietly to herself, for of course no one ever saw a darning-needle laugh.

author: HCAndersen
text: And there she sat as proudly as if she were in a state coach, and looked all around her.

author: HCAndersen
text: "May I be allowed to ask if you are made of gold?" she inquired of her neighbor, a pin; "you have a very pretty appearance, and a curious head, although you are rather small.

author: HCAndersen
text: You must take pains to grow, for it is not every one who has sealing-wax dropped upon him;" and as she spoke, the darning-needle drew herself up so proudly that she fell out of the handkerchief right into the sink, which the cook was cleaning.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now I am going on a journey," said the needle, as she floated away with the dirty water, "I do hope I shall not be lost."

author: HCAndersen
text: But she really was lost in a gutter.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I am too fine for this world," said the darning-needle, as she lay in the gutter; "but I know who I am, and that is always some comfort."

author: HCAndersen
text: So the darning-needle kept up her proud behavior, and did not lose her good humor.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then there floated over her all sorts of things,- chips and straws, and pieces of old newspaper.

author: HCAndersen
text: "See how they sail," said the darning-needle; "they do not know what is under them.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am here, and here I shall stick.

author: HCAndersen
text: See, there goes a chip, thinking of nothing in the world but himself- only a chip.

author: HCAndersen
text: There's a straw going by now; how he turns and twists about!

author: HCAndersen
text: Don't be thinking too much of yourself, or you may chance to run against a stone.

author: HCAndersen
text: There swims a piece of newspaper; what is written upon it has been forgotten long ago, and yet it gives itself airs.

author: HCAndersen
text: I sit here patiently and quietly.

author: HCAndersen
text: I know who I am, so I shall not move."

author: HCAndersen
text: One day something lying close to the darning-needle glittered so splendidly that she thought it was a diamond; yet it was only a piece of broken bottle.

author: HCAndersen
text: The darning-needle spoke to it, because it sparkled, and represented herself as a breast-pin.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I suppose you are really a diamond?" she said.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Why yes, something of the kind," he replied; and so each believed the other to be very valuable, and then they began to talk about the world, and the conceited people in it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I have been in a lady's work-box," said the darning-needle, "and this lady was the cook.

author: HCAndersen
text: She had on each hand five fingers, and anything so conceited as these five fingers I have never seen; and yet they were only employed to take me out of the box and to put me back again."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Were they not high-born?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "High-born!" said the darning-needle, "no indeed, but so haughty.

author: HCAndersen
text: They were five brothers, all born fingers; they kept very proudly together, though they were of different lengths.

author: HCAndersen
text: The one who stood first in the rank was named the thumb, he was short and thick, and had only one joint in his back, and could therefore make but one bow; but he said that if he were cut off from a man's hand, that man would be unfit for a soldier.

author: HCAndersen
text: Sweet-tooth, his neighbor, dipped himself into sweet or sour, pointed to the sun and moon, and formed the letters when the fingers wrote.

author: HCAndersen
text: Longman, the middle finger, looked over the heads of all the others.

author: HCAndersen
text: Gold-band, the next finger, wore a golden circle round his waist.

author: HCAndersen
text: And little Playman did nothing at all, and seemed proud of it.

author: HCAndersen
text: They were boasters, and boasters they will remain; and therefore I left them."

author: HCAndersen
text: "And now we sit here and glitter," said the piece of broken bottle.

author: HCAndersen
text: At the same moment more water streamed into the gutter, so that it overflowed, and the piece of bottle was carried away.

author: HCAndersen
text: "So he is promoted," said the darning-needle, "while I remain here; I am too fine, but that is my pride, and what do I care?"

author: HCAndersen
text: And so she sat there in her pride, and had many such thoughts as these,- "I could almost fancy that I came from a sunbeam, I am so fine.

author: HCAndersen
text: It seems as if the sunbeams were always looking for me under the water.

author: HCAndersen
text: Ah!

author: HCAndersen
text: I am so fine that even my mother cannot find me.

author: HCAndersen
text: Had I still my old eye, which was broken off, I believe I should weep; but no, I would not do that, it is not genteel to cry."

author: HCAndersen
text: One day a couple of street boys were paddling in the gutter, for they sometimes found old nails, farthings, and other treasures.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was dirty work, but they took great pleasure in it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Hallo!" cried one, as he pricked himself with the darning-needle, "here's a fellow for you."

author: HCAndersen
text: "I am not a fellow, I am a young lady," said the darning-needle; but no one heard her.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sealing-wax had come off, and she was quite black; but black makes a person look slender, so she thought herself even finer than before.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Here comes an egg-shell sailing along," said one of the boys; so they stuck the darning-needle into the egg-shell.

author: HCAndersen
text: "White walls, and I am black myself," said the darning-needle, "that looks well; now I can be seen, but I hope I shall not be sea-sick, or I shall break again."

author: HCAndersen
text: She was not sea-sick, and she did not break.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is a good thing against sea-sickness to have a steel stomach, and not to forget one's own importance.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now my sea-sickness has past: delicate people can bear a great deal."

author: HCAndersen
text: Crack went the egg-shell, as a waggon passed over it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Good heavens, how it crushes!" said the darning-needle.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I shall be sick now.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am breaking!" but she did not break, though the waggon went over her as she lay at full length; and there let her lie.
